1: <sup>1</sup> I made a covenant with mine eyes; why then should I think upon a maid?
2: <sup>2</sup> For what portion of God is there from above? and what inheritance of the Almighty from on high?
3: <sup>3</sup> Is not destruction to the wicked? and a strange punishment to the workers of iniquity?
4: <sup>4</sup> Doth not he see my ways, and count all my steps?
5: <sup>5</sup> If I have walked with vanity, or if my foot hath hasted to deceit;
6: <sup>6</sup> Let me be weighed in an even balance that God may know mine integrity.
7: <sup>7</sup> If my step hath turned out of the way, and mine heart walked after mine eyes, and if any blot hath cleaved to mine hands;
8: <sup>8</sup> Then let me sow, and let another eat; yea, let my offspring be rooted out.
9: <sup>9</sup> If mine heart have been deceived by a woman, or if I have laid wait at my neighbour’s door;
10: <sup>10</sup> Then let my wife grind unto another, and let others bow down upon her.
11: <sup>11</sup> For this is an heinous crime; yea, it is an iniquity to be punished by the judges.
12: <sup>12</sup> For it is a fire that consumeth to destruction, and would root out all mine increase.
13: <sup>13</sup> If I did despise the cause of my manservant or of my maidservant, when they contended with me;
14: <sup>14</sup> What then shall I do when God riseth up? and when he visiteth, what shall I answer him?
15: <sup>15</sup> Did not he that made me in the womb make him? and did not one fashion us in the womb?
16: <sup>16</sup> If I have withheld the poor from their desire, or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail;
17: <sup>17</sup> Or have eaten my morsel myself alone, and the fatherless hath not eaten thereof;
18: <sup>18</sup> (For from my youth he was brought up with me, as with a father, and I have guided her from my mother’s womb;)
19: <sup>19</sup> If I have seen any perish for want of clothing, or any poor without covering;
20: <sup>20</sup> If his loins have not blessed me, and if he were not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
21: <sup>21</sup> If I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless, when I saw my help in the gate:
22: <sup>22</sup> Then let mine arm fall from my shoulder blade, and mine arm be broken from the bone.
23: <sup>23</sup> For destruction from God was a terror to me, and by reason of his highness I could not endure.
24: <sup>24</sup> If I have made gold my hope, or have said to the fine gold, Thou art my confidence;
25: <sup>25</sup> If I rejoice because my wealth was great, and because mine hand had gotten much;
26: <sup>26</sup> If I beheld the sun when it shined, or the moon walking in brightness;
27: <sup>27</sup> And my heart hath been secretly enticed, or my mouth hath kissed my hand:
28: <sup>28</sup> This also were an iniquity to be punished by the judge: for I should have denied the God that is above.
29: <sup>29</sup> If I rejoice at the destruction of him that hated me, or lifted up myself when evil found him:
30: <sup>30</sup> Neither have I suffered my mouth to sin by wishing a curse to his soul.
31: <sup>31</sup> If the men of my tabernacle said not, Oh that we had of his flesh! we cannot be satisfied.
32: <sup>32</sup> The stranger did not lodge in the street: but I opened my doors to the traveller.
33: <sup>33</sup> If I covered my transgressions as Adam, by hiding mine iniquity in my bosom:
34: <sup>34</sup> Did I fear a great multitude, or did the contempt of families terrify me, that I kept silence, and went not out of the door?
35: <sup>35</sup> Oh that one would hear me! behold, my desire is, that the Almighty would answer me, and that mine adversary had written a book.
36: <sup>36</sup> Surely I would take it upon my shoulder, and bind it as a crown to me.
37: <sup>37</sup> I would declare unto him the number of my steps; as a prince would I go near unto him.
38: <sup>38</sup> If my land cry against me, or that the furrows likewise thereof complain;
39: <sup>39</sup> If I have eaten the fruits thereof without money, or have caused the owners thereof to lose their life:
40: <sup>40</sup> Let thistles grow instead of wheat, and cockle instead of barley. The words of Job are ended.
